title: improve hub check or check for duplicate output prefixes
body:
I now had a couple of times the issue that the track hubs that I configured contained some duplication on some level. 
So we could either think about checking for this on our own or we should think about using the hub_check utility from UCSC to test wether the current track hub configuration works, see here (https://genome.ucsc.edu/goldenpath/help/hgTrackHubHelp.html#Debug).

There are multiple ways to tackle this with the tool: 
First
 - wait until most of the steps are done and then print a warning (not the best option)
 - do a dry-run for the hub-creation in a sub directory, where every necessary file is touched (like touching make_ucsc_hub.input files) (my favorite)
Then use the hub_check utility. 

The benefit of checking on our own is clearly that we don't need further dependencies and we can check for this already during the validation step in the driver script.

- [ ] check for proper type values
- [ ] check for duplicate prefixes in output files

title: Improve Memory usage for some Rules
body:
I'll just open this for book keeping. 

In general we can only tweak some rules, that have a very high memory footprint, due too loading whole files into memory.

Rules that might be improved (selected only from memory requirement): 
 - summarize_data_for_report
 - peak_statistics
 - knit_report
 - extract_signal_annotation
 - extract_signal_peaks
 - annotate_peaks

Let's try to improve this at some point.

title: ordering of hub tracks is lost

title: broad peaks have to be defined for every Peak sample
body:
if broad argument is given to general macs2 settings like this:
```
general:
  assembly: hg19
  params:
    extend: 200
    scale_bw: 'no'
    bowtie2:
        k: 4
        X: 2000
        local: ''
        no-discordant: ''
        no-mixed: ''
    idr:
        idr-threshold: 0.1
    macs2:
        g: hs
        keep-dup: 1
        q: 0.05
        format: 'BAMPE'
        nomodel: ''
        shift: -100
        extsize: 200
        broad: ''
```
Then snakemake will not know that all samples should be handled as broad peaks, 
because the macs2 suffix `broadPeak` is derived from `CUSTOM_PARAMS` dict. 

Right now the way to handle this is to add the custom param `broad` to every sample.


A solution to this issue could be that we use the custom params to overwrite the default general settings (i.e. config dict) on a per sample basis, such that we do not have to deal with two dictionaries to handle settings.

title: remove the chipqc.rmd
body:
there is still the template from chipqc package included, this has to be removed. 

see https://github.com/BIMSBbioinfo/pigx_chipseq/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=ChIPQC.rmd&type=

title: Do we need to keep the scorematrices ?
body:
The step `knit report` requires a way too large amount of memory, because the RDS created at `Extract_Signal_Annotation` (https://github.com/BIMSBbioinfo/pigx_chipseq/blob/master/scripts/Extract_Signal_Annotation.R#L63) keeps the 11 scorematrixlist objects for every genomic annotation with a scorematrix for every sample in `lsml` list, even though the profile signal is already summarized in `profiles` tibble. 
The same `lsml` lists is passed to `Summarize_Data_For_Report`, which leads to the large memory footprint. 

In my example analysis I have 16 samples and the `lstats$Extract_Signal_Annotation$lsml` alone is 28G, without actually beeing used.

title: Harmonize documentation, every pipeline should have similar section names and flow
body:
# goal
use the following general structure.

# Introduction
Example: PiGx RNA-seq is a preprocessing and analysis pipeline. It takes single-end or paired-end fastq files containing fragment reads, and does all the necessary preprocessing to get analysis-ready gene expression levels. It also performs quality control steps and outputs comprehensive quality statistics. Finally, it performs a differential expression analysis and outputs a stand-alone HTML report with tables and figures summarizing any differential gene expression between samples as specified in the experiment design.

## workflow
Describe the main workflow steps in bullet points, put the workflow picture

## output
Describe the output in bullet points. Example:
- QC reports
- bam files
- bigwig files
- narrowPeak files
- UCSC track hub folder

# Installation
Show users how to install it. If you want to list dependencies etc, this is the place. If you want to show how to install via conda this is the place. You can have extra subsections if you need.

# Quick Start [This should be done asap if possible ]
put the test data somewhere online, show users how to download it and run it

# Preparing the input
Here we describe how to prepare the sample sheet and the settings file
## sample sheet
- [Describe what is in the sample sheet in detail, show an example, explain columns]
- [ show how to initialize settings file via --init=sample-sheet]

## settings file
- [Describe what is in the settings file in detail, show an example if possible ]
- [ show how to initialize settings file via --init=settings]


# Running the pipeline
Describe how to run the pipeline. Describe additional arguments here if you need to. Such as 
  --target -n, --dry-run, --unlock etc.
You can explain a couple important ones and direct users to use help for the rest. subsections such as "resource consideration" etc can go here.
If there are differences for running on the cluster or locally these should go here. See RNA-seq documentation for such a description

# Output description
Describe what pipeline outputs and if there is specific directory structure describe it here.
There can be subsections here such as "Downstream analysis" if need be

# Troubleshooting/FAQ
List potential issues and solutions here

# Questions
If you have further questions please e-mail:
pigx@googlegroups.com or use the web form to ask questions
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/pigx/

title: Check for missing gsize in macs2 options
body:
The default settings file contains an empty `g:` (`--gsize`)  option for macs2 general params. 
This should definitely checked before executing the pipeline. 

There are other solutions to omit the gsize option and derive the argument from the input data or the settings input.

1. we could derive the g from the assembly, for instance if we get the "ce11" assembly we know the `gsize` will be "ce" 

 - this option will be very error prone if users use an ensembl assembly,  or if the organism has no built-in value in macs2 

2. derive the genome size from the reference fasta file

- the reference file is anyways a required input of the pipeline, so it will always be available
- we just need to derive this value from the chromosome sizes
- **maybe we can use the chrom_size file to do it on the fly**

title: scripts may have to be wrapped in well-known environment
body:
When submitting jobs to the cluster, they run in an environment that ought to be the same as the environment that they were spawned in.  This is not guaranteed behaviour, though, despite the fact that we use `qsub -V`.  The `-V` flag causes processes to run in shell sessions that load the user's shell initialisations --- that's not the same as forcing the same environment.

To make the R scripts behave the way we expect them to, we need to wrap them in a shell wrapper that first sets `R_LIBS_SITE`.  That way we can safely ignore any user settings and maybe even throw out the misleading `-V` flag.

We can do this in Guix, but it would be lovely if we could find a way to do this no matter how PiGx is installed.

title: Cluster execution is much slower than local execution
body:
I ran this:

    pigx-chipseq -s Tests/settings.yaml Tests/sample_sheet.csv

I reduced the number of threads for the peak_statistics rule from 16 to 2 in "Tests/settings.yaml", because the default of 16 threads with 16GB each meant that I could not get a 256GB memory slot on the cluster.

Now, it is expected that things will be slower when using fewer threads, but this pipeline has been running for an hour or more.  It seems to me that it is generally slower when submitting jobs to the cluster, but I haven't been able to compare the execution times.

title: Elaborate more about the details inferring genome size from input genome.
body:
from version v0.0.18 we start to infer the genome size for peak calling from the provided genome file, before we set this using instead of using macs available defaults. 
This changes the background normalizations and hence the peaks will differ.


this was introduced to reduce the number of arguments needed to be filled out by the user, but it could be a source of variation if users provide different genomes for different runs on the same fastq files.


> the user should expect different results when they use a different genome, right ?
there will be already variation if you use the canonical form vs complete genome

>the same would apply to re-running the analysis with a different user input genome size (edited)
> the results would change

yes, but if user sets `hs` or `mm` as value, then it will always be the same …
Anyways, in general using the size of the provided genome is a better way of controlling it. 
I just need to write somewhere that the results could differ if user decides to change/reduce the genome.

body:
Hi,

this is my first time trying to run pigz and touching guix, so I will try to go by the documentation and put my questions here so we can improve the documentation.

# Installation
After `guix package -i pigx-chipseq` and putting guix in my PATH as proposed by guix (`export PATH="/home/cmessers/.guix-profile/bin${PATH:+:}$PATH"`), do I need to run `guix environment -l guix.scm`? Apparently the last command generates an environment for development, but to use the pipeline it does not appear to be necessary.


# command name?

In my installation, the command appears to be `pigx-chipseq` and not `pigx chipseq` as the docs say.

# Replicates

The docs say
> The current sample sheet does not support multiple technical replicates for one sample, so replicates need to be combined prior to running the pipeline.

i get that this is a limitation of MACS2. How should biological replicates be handled?

Further, I was confused by the sample sheet regarding this same point.

The example includes

```
    Peaks4:
        ChIP:
            # multiple samples can be used as treatment
            - ChIP1
            - ChIP2
        Cont:
            # multiple samples can be used as control
            - Cont1
            - Cont2
```

So how are ChIP1 and ChIP2 handled here?

Otherwise the running the tests went fine.

Thanks for the effort,
Clemens

title: export report figures as pdf
introduce hard trimming option ?
body:
one can easily set hard trimming in trim galore using `--hardtrim5 x` or `--hardtrim3 y` options, but the output files have a different naming: `.xbp_5prime.fq.gz` / `.ybp_3prime.fq.gz`. This causes the pipeline to fail on the following steps.  

Maybe we could add a global option to hardtrimming and resolve this naming pattern to what we need.

body: ading arguments to the tools in the config file does not change the setting for trimming, as we did not parse tool args in the rule

title: symlink as fasta fails
body:
If the user sets the fasta path to a symbolic link that points to the original fasta file we fail when trying to link the genome.

The. problem is that right now the filetype detected with magic is 'inode/symlink’, 
which is why we get the 'Unknow input genome file format’ error. 

However this happens not during initial checkup, but during the pipeline run, which is bad.

title: validate all settings in the settings file before starting snakemake
body:
If the user creates a settings file, where a the tools paragraph is actually empty like in the example below:
```
general:
[..]
    bowtie2:
        # set k if you want to report at most k alignments per read
        # k: 1
        # N: Sets the number of mismatches to allowed in a seed alignment during multiseed alignment. Can be set to 0 or 1. Setting this higher makes alignment slower (often much slower) but increases sensitivity. Default: 0.
        # N: 0
[...]
```

We get a cryptic error later in the pipeline:

```
message)[0m
[31mRuleException:
TypeError in line 174 of /gnu/store/nxk52pcmvizq6vlb4xmg2x0c3s74xprb-pigx-chipseq-0.0.42/libexec/pigx_chipseq/scripts/SnakeFunctions.py:
'NoneType' object is not iterable
  File "/gnu/store/nxk52pcmvizq6vlb4xmg2x0c3s74xprb-pigx-chipseq-0.0.42/libexec/pigx_chipseq/Rules/Mapping.py", line 220, in __rule_bowtie2
  File "/gnu/store/nxk52pcmvizq6vlb4xmg2x0c3s74xprb-pigx-chipseq-0.0.42/libexec/pigx_chipseq/scripts/SnakeFunctions.py", line 174, in join_params
  File "/gnu/store/09a5iq080g9b641jyl363dr5jkkvnhcn-python-3.8.2/lib/python3.8/concurrent/futures/thread.py", line 57, in run[0m
```

We need to validate this earlier.

title: print tables reporting encode quality control metrics
body:
https://www.encodeproject.org/atac-seq/

> - Experiments should have two or more biological replicates. Assays performed using EN-TEx samples may be exempted due to limited availability of experimental material, but at least two technical replicates are required. 
> - Each replicate should have 25 million non-duplicate, non-mitochondrial aligned reads for single-end sequencing and 50 million for paired-ended sequencing (i.e. 25 million fragments, regardless of sequencing run type). 
> - The alignment rate, or percentage of mapped reads, should be greater than 95%, though values >80% may be acceptable. 
> - Replicate concordance is measured by calculating IDR values (Irreproducible Discovery Rate). The experiment passes if both rescue and self consistency ratios are less than 2.
> - Library complexity is measured using the Non-Redundant Fraction (NRF) and PCR Bottlenecking Coefficients 1 and 2, or PBC1 and PBC2. The preferred values are as follows: NRF>0.9, PBC1>0.9, and PBC2>3. 
> - Various peak files must meet certain requirements. Please visit the section on output files under the pipeline overview for more information on peak files.
>   - The number of peaks within a replicated peak file should be >150,000, though values >100,000 may be acceptable. 
>   - The number of peaks within an IDR peak file should be >70,000, though values >50,000 may be acceptable.
>   - A nucleosome free region (NFR) must be present.
>   - A mononucleosome peak must be present in the fragment length distribution. These are reads that span a single nucleosome, so they are longer than 147 bp but shorter than 147*2 bp. Good ATAC-seq datasets have reads that span nucleosomes (which allows for calling nucleosome positions in addition to open regions of chromatin).
> - The fraction of reads in called peak regions (FRiP score) should be >0.3, though values greater than 0.2 are acceptable. For EN-TEx tissues, FRiP scores will not be enforced as QC metric. TSS enrichment remains in place as a key signal to noise measure.
> - Transcription start site (TSS) enrichment values are dependent on the reference files used; cutoff values for high quality data are listed in the table below.

title: bug with names of differential_analysis
body:
Error occured, If names for the differential analysis is 

"CCRepro_vs_CCNormal:" and "CCRepro_vs_CCNormal_NFR:"

```
InputFunctionException in line 185 of /gnu/store/0fjyszb91qqki545krh0j3244932c1c7-pigx-chipseq-0.0.51/libexec/pigx_chipseq/Rules/Mapping.py:
KeyError: '_NFR_BT_IO_02_bat2088_D1_CCRepro_I'
Wildcards:
genome_type=Main
name=_NFR_BT_IO_02_bat2088_D1_CCRepro_I
```

The reason is probably the similarity of the two names, since keeping only one analysis is fine. 
One fix is to omit the last underscore to change the `CCNormal_NFR` to `CCNormalNFR`, which renders it another word that can be filled by the snakemake interpolation.

title: cryptic error when gtf annotation is missing
body:
When the gtf-file is not given, or commented, a cryptic error message is given. 

test.yaml:
```
# ## ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~LOCATIONS~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ #
# ## This section needs to be adjusted to the planned analysis.   #
# ## ------------------------------------------------------------ #
 locations:
   input-dir: ./
   output-dir: ./output
   genome-file: ../dm_genome/Drosophila_melanogaster_sm_assembly6_chip.fa
#   spikein-file:
#   index-dir:
#   gff-file:
#
#
[..]
```

```
SyntaxError:
Input and output files have to be specified as strings or lists of strings.
  File "/gnu/store/1d1y4d7j8p4cnad7q9mswhbvs18falp6-pigx-chipseq-0.0.52/libexec/pigx_chipseq/Snake_ChIPseq.py", line 364, in <module>
  File "/gnu/store/1d1y4d7j8p4cnad7q9mswhbvs18falp6-pigx-chipseq-0.0.52/libexec/pigx_chipseq/Rules/Prepare_Annotation.py", line 11, in <module>

```

title: update faq about gtf headers
body:
The user needs to remove the header from the corresponding GTF annotation file for the pipeline to run 

```sed '/^#/d' annotation_file.gtf > annotation_file_no_header.gtf```

body:
Otherwise the execution may fail with: 

```
Error in as(object, "GRanges") :
  no method or default for coercing "numeric" to "GRanges"
Calls: Extend_Regions ... export.bw -> export -> export -> export -> export -> as
Execution halted
```

https://github.com/BIMSBbioinfo/pigx_chipseq/blob/0ef20c7f1d9ed96b653870f137b7038f80044b30/scripts/BigWigExtend.R#L80

title: no version shown upon `--version`
m4/ax_r_package.m4 is outdated
body: The old m4 macro leads to configure errors under some circumstances.  It should be updated, e.g. to the version used by pigx-rnaseq.

title: interactive table with links to igv browsable regions
body:
We can subset to only open regions within promoters and then create a HTML table to review the results in IGV using the makebedtable() function in tracktables package.

https://rockefelleruniversity.github.io/RU_ATACseq/presentations/slides/RU_ATAC_part2.html#53
